question: why are south east asians and black ethnicities more prone to diabetes

clueweb22-en0031-74-14899.point_content: People from Black African, African Caribbean and South Asian (Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi) backgrounds are at a higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes from a younger age.
spans: People from Black African, African Caribbean and South Asian (Indian, Pakistani, Bangladeshi) backgrounds are at a higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes from a younger age.

clueweb22-en0031-74-14899.point_content: Family history, and social and environmental factors play a part in increased risk of type 2 diabetes among certain ethnicities, but it is still not clear why people from certain ethnic backgrounds have an increased risk.
spans: Family history, and social and environmental factors play a part. But it is still not clear why people from certain ethnic backgrounds have an increased risk.

clueweb22-en0031-74-14899.point_content: People from South Asian backgrounds are more likely to experience insulin resistance at a younger age, possibly linked to how fat is stored in the body, particularly visceral fat around the middle and important organs like the liver and pancreas.
spans: People from South Asian backgrounds for example are more likely to experience insulin resistance at a younger age.
This could be linked to how fat is stored in the body and particularly around the middle.
This is known as visceral fat and it can build up around important organs like the liver and pancreas.

clueweb22-en0031-74-14899.point_content: Insulin resistance leads to an increased chance of having high blood sugar levels, which if left untreated can lead to health complications.
spans: Insulin resistance is when insulin can’t work properly leading to an increased chance of having high blood sugar levels. If left untreated over time, high blood sugar levels can lead to lots of health complications.

clueweb22-en0031-74-14899.point_content: People from Black African, African Caribbean and South Asian backgrounds are at risk of developing type 2 diabetes from the age of 25, younger than the white population whose risk increases from 40.
spans: People from Black African, African Caribbean and South Asian backgrounds are at risk of developing type 2 diabetes from the age of 25.
This is much younger than the white population, as their risk increases from 40.

clueweb22-en0028-20-09724.point_content: Ethnicity can increase or decrease one’s risk of developing diabetes.
spans: ethnicity can increase or decrease one’s risk of developing diabetes

clueweb22-en0028-20-09724.point_content: Even with equal access to healthcare, prevalence of diabetes differs between people of different ethnicity.
spans: even with equal access prevalence of diabetes differs between people of different ethnicity

clueweb22-en0028-20-09724.point_content: Type 2 diabetes is up to 6 times more likely in people of South Asian descent.
spans: Type 2 diabetes is up to 6 times more likely in people of South Asian descent

clueweb22-en0028-20-09724.point_content: Type 2 diabetes is up to three times more likely in African and Africa-Caribbean people.
spans: Type 2 diabetes is up to three times more likely in African and Africa-Caribbean people

clueweb22-en0003-43-12507.point_content: At the same BMI, Asians have more than double the risk of developing type 2 diabetes than whites; Hispanics and blacks also had higher risks of diabetes than whites, but to a lesser degree.
spans: Asians had more than double the risk of developing type 2 diabetes than whites; Hispanics and blacks also had higher risks of diabetes than whites, but to a lesser degree

clueweb22-en0003-43-12507.point_content: For every 11 pounds Asians gained during adulthood, they had an 84 percent increase in their risk of type 2 diabetes; weight gain was more harmful in Asians than in other ethnic groups.
spans: For every 11 pounds Asians gained during adulthood, they had an 84 percent increase in their risk of type 2 diabetes

clueweb22-en0003-43-12507.point_content: Asians have 3 to 5 percent higher total body fat compared to white Europeans of the same BMI, which may explain higher disease risk.
spans: When compared to white Europeans of the same BMI, Asians have 3 to 5 percent higher total body fat

clueweb22-en0003-43-12507.point_content: South Asians have especially high levels of body fat and are more prone to developing abdominal obesity, which may account for their very high risk of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease.
spans: South Asians, in particular, have especially high levels of body fat and are more prone to developing abdominal obesity, which may account for their very high risk of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease

clueweb22-en0003-43-12507.point_content: Blacks have lower body fat and higher lean muscle mass than whites at the same BMI, which may mean lower risk of obesity-related diseases at the same BMI, but overall obesity prevalence is higher in blacks in the U.S.
spans: some studies have found that blacks have lower body fat and higher lean muscle mass than whites at the same BMI
in the U.S., the prevalence of obesity is higher in non-Hispanic blacks than in non-Hispanic whites

clueweb22-en0003-43-12507.point_content: Environmental factors such as under-nutrition during fetal life followed by nutritionally rich environments later may increase diabetes risk in Asians.
spans: research suggests that under-nutrition during fetal life, such as during the Chinese famine of 1954 to 1964, raises the risk of diabetes in adulthood, especially when individuals live in nutritionally rich environments later in life

clueweb22-en0043-05-17998.point_content: People of minority ethnic groups make up just over a quarter of dental practitioners, medical practitioners and opticians. They are also more likely to be nurses, medical radiographers, nursing auxiliaries and assistants and technicians.
spans: People of minority ethnic groups make up just over a quarter of dental practitioners, medical practitioners and opticians. They are also more likely to be nurses, medical radiographers, nursing auxiliaries and assistants and technicians.

clueweb22-en0043-05-17998.point_content: Black and Asian men are more likely to have a job associated with higher COVID-19 death rates.
spans: Black and Asian men are more likely to have a job associated with higher COVID-19 death rates.

clueweb22-en0043-05-17998.point_content: Of working men, Black and Asian men are more likely to work in occupations that have had a higher risk of death involving COVID-19.
spans: We also found from deaths data that, of working men, Black and Asian men are more likely to work in occupations that have had a higher risk of death involving COVID-19.

clueweb22-en0043-05-17998.point_content: People of minority ethnic groups are more likely to live in urban or more deprived areas, where death rates from COVID-19 are higher.
spans: Most ethnic minorities are more likely to live in urban or more deprived areas, where death rates from COVID-19 are higher.

clueweb22-en0043-05-17998.point_content: Those with Bangladeshi and Pakistani, and Black ethnic backgrounds have been the most likely to live in deprived neighbourhoods, according to the census.
spans: Those with Bangladeshi and Pakistani, and Black ethnic backgrounds have been the most likely to live in deprived neighbourhoods, according to the census.

clueweb22-en0019-06-00542.point_content: South Asians living in the U.S. generally have lower levels of 'good' HDL cholesterol than their white counterparts, which is a risk factor for heart disease.
spans: South Asians living in the U.S. generally have lower levels of "good" HDL cholesterol than their white counterparts.

clueweb22-en0019-06-00542.point_content: People of South Asian descent have a higher risk of developing heart disease than the general American population.
spans: people of South Asian descent – those from Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka – have a higher risk of developing heart disease than the general American population.

clueweb22-en0019-06-00542.point_content: Each ethnicity has some clusters of risk factors specific to that ethnic group, which could be genetic or related to lifestyle.
spans: Each ethnicity has some clusters of risk factors specific to that ethnic group, Virani said.
Some of those could be genetic, some could be related to acquired traits related to lifestyle specific to an ethnic group.

clueweb22-en0019-06-00542.point_content: The guidelines describe race and ethnic backgrounds as 'risk-proj-t-3jM9g14yGtzozJKYlWdtPW3nCuv8MoCKAkJPlQS7cBygKF6ur3tLm-pGfCEHxg5Jkk7lohYET3BlbkFJYfa6MImXvTLilGultWkvXMY8Cdcr6lofi2WkCxxuTZr37mtK8de78smZCWM3yLF6PiNIeNWEoA factors' for specific U.S. populations, indicating ethnicity matters in cardiovascular risk assessment.
spans: the guidelines also described race and ethnic backgrounds as "risk-proj-t-3jM9g14yGtzozJKYlWdtPW3nCuv8MoCKAkJPlQS7cBygKF6ur3tLm-pGfCEHxg5Jkk7lohYET3BlbkFJYfa6MImXvTLilGultWkvXMY8Cdcr6lofi2WkCxxuTZr37mtK8de78smZCWM3yLF6PiNIeNWEoA factors" for specific U.S. populations.
"Ethnicity matters. We've known that for a while," said Dr. Salim Virani

clueweb22-en0041-38-11456.point_content: Asians, especially South Asians, are more likely to have less muscle and more abdominal fat, which increases insulin resistance.
spans: This higher risk may be because Asians, especially South Asians, are more likely to have less muscle and more abdominal fat, which increases insulin resistance.

clueweb22-en0041-38-11456.point_content: Indian newborns have higher levels of body fat and insulin despite lower average body weight compared to white newborns.
spans: even though Indian newborns have a lower average body weight compared to white newborns, Indian newborns have higher levels of body fat and insulin.

clueweb22-en0041-38-11456.point_content: Asians of a healthy BMI have more fat around organs and in the belly area than Europeans with the same BMI.
spans: Imaging technology that measures fat in humans has shown that Asians of a healthy BMI have more fat around organs and in the belly area than Europeans with the same BMI.

clueweb22-en0041-38-11456.point_content: An “apple-shaped body” with excess fat around the waist increases diabetes risk even if BMI is normal.
spans: Even if you have a normal BMI, an “apple-shaped body” (with excess fat around the waist) increases your diabetes risk.

clueweb22-en0041-38-11456.point_content: Urbanization and modernization have led to less physical activity among Asians, increasing diabetes risk.
spans: Urbanization and modernization have led to less walking, less biking, and less daily physical activity.

clueweb22-en0041-38-11456.point_content: Nearly 50% of adult men in Asian countries smoke regularly, which is associated with higher abdominal fat and a 45% increased risk of developing diabetes.
spans: Nearly 50% of adult men in Asian countries smoke regularly, 1 which is associated with higher abdominal fat and a 45% increased risk of developing diabetes.

clueweb22-en0041-38-11456.point_content: White rice and other refined grains, linked to increased diabetes risk, make up a large proportion of daily energy intake in Asian diets.
spans: White rice and other refined grains, which are linked to increased risk of diabetes, make up a large proportion of daily energy intake in Asian diets.

clueweb22-en0041-38-11456.point_content: Unhealthy trans fats and saturated fats, such as palm oil, are often used as cooking oils in Asian diets.
spans: Unhealthy trans fats and saturated fats, such as palm oil, are often used as cooking oils.

clueweb22-en0041-38-11456.point_content: Frequent consumption of Western-style fast food increases diabetes risk among Asians.
spans: In one Singapore study of more than 43,000 Chinese adults, those who ate Western-style fast food more than twice a week had a 27% increased risk of developing diabetes compared to those who reported eating little or no fast food.

clueweb22-en0041-38-11456.point_content: Poor maternal nutrition during pregnancy increases the child's risk of high blood sugar and diabetes later in life.
spans: Poor nutrition when a mother is pregnant means that when that the baby grows up, he or she will be more likely to have high blood sugar, especially if rapidly transitioning to a diet high in refined carbohydrates, sugary beverages, or fatty Western fast foods.

clueweb22-en0041-38-11456.point_content: Air pollution may increase risk of insulin resistance and diabetes.
spans: Air pollution, an increasing problem in Asia, may also increase risk of insulin resistance and diabetes.
